title: Modeling a Periodic Context - Angle in Metronome

content.description:
The metronome is a chunky, triangular pyramid-shaped device with a pendulum that moves back and forth from right to left, which is indicated by a curved arrow at the top of the figure.

The centerline is vertical and is in the middle of the metronome with markings.

The pendulum is a thin rod that forms an angle with the centerline as it moves back and forth from right to left.

The angle formed is labeled h of t.

Note that the figure is not drawn to scale.

A metronome is a device used to help musicians play music at a particular speed. The metronome has a vertical centerline, as shown in the figure. A pendulum on the metronome swings back and forth as it passes the vertical centerline. When the pendulum is farthest to the left or farthest to the right, the measure of the angle formed by the pendulum and the vertical centerline is <math alttext="0.5"><mn>0.5</mn></math> radian.

At time <math alttext="t equals 0"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> seconds, the pendulum is farthest to the left. The pendulum then swings to the right and passes the vertical centerline. At time <math alttext="t equals 2"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math> seconds, the pendulum is farthest to the right for the first time. Then, the pendulum swings left, passes the vertical centerline, and is farthest to the left again at time <math alttext="t equals 4"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math> seconds. As the pendulum swings, the measure of the angle formed by the pendulum and the vertical centerline periodically increases and decreases.

The sinusoidal function <math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math> models the measure of the angle, in radians, formed by the pendulum and the vertical centerline as a function of time <math alttext="t"><mi>t</mi></math>, in seconds. A negative value of <math alttext="h open parentheses t close parentheses"><mi>h</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced></math> indicates the pendulum is to the left of the vertical centerline; a positive value of <math alttext="h open parentheses t close parentheses"><mi>h</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced></math> indicates the pendulum is to the right of the vertical centerline.

Part A

The graph of <math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math> and its dashed midline for two full cycles is shown. Five points, <math alttext="F"><mi>F</mi></math>, <math alttext="G"><mi>G</mi></math>, <math alttext="J"><mi>J</mi></math>, <math alttext="K"><mi>K</mi></math>, and <math alttext="P"><mi>P</mi></math>, are labeled on the graph. No scale is indicated, and no axes are presented.

Determine possible coordinates <math alttext="open parentheses t comma h open parentheses t close parentheses close parentheses"><mfenced><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>h</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced></mrow></mfenced></math> for the five points: <math alttext="F"><mi>F</mi></math>, <math alttext="G"><mi>G</mi></math>, <math alttext="J"><mi>J</mi></math>, <math alttext="K"><mi>K</mi></math>, and <math alttext="P"><mi>P</mi></math>.

Moving from left to right:

Point F is at a maximum point.

Point G is on the midline.

Point J is at a minimum point.

Point K is on the midline.

Point P is at a maximum point.

Part A

Five points, <math alttext="F"><mi>F</mi></math>, <math alttext="G"><mi>G</mi></math>, <math alttext="J"><mi>J</mi></math>, <math alttext="K"><mi>K</mi></math>, and <math alttext="P"><mi>P</mi></math>, are labeled on the graph. No scale is indicated, and no axes are presented.

Determine possible coordinates <math alttext="open parentheses t comma h open parentheses t close parentheses close parentheses"><mfenced><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>h</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced></mrow></mfenced></math> for the five points: <math alttext="F"><mi>F</mi></math>, <math alttext="G"><mi>G</mi></math>, <math alttext="J"><mi>J</mi></math>, <math alttext="K"><mi>K</mi></math>, and <math alttext="P"><mi>P</mi></math>.

Moving from left to right:

Point G is on the midline.

Point J is at a minimum point.

Part B

The function <math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math> can be written in the form <math alttext="h open parentheses t close parentheses equals a cos open parentheses b open parentheses t plus c close parentheses close parentheses plus d"><mi>h</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>cos</mi><mfenced><mrow><mi>b</mi><mfenced><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mi>d</mi></math>. Find values of constants <math alttext="a"><mi>a</mi></math>, <math alttext="b"><mi>b</mi></math>, <math alttext="c"><mi>c</mi></math>, and <math alttext="d"><mi>d</mi></math>.

Part C

Refer to the graph of <math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math> in part A. The <math alttext="t"><mi>t</mi></math>-coordinate of <math alttext="J"><mi>J</mi></math> is <math alttext="t subscript 1"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, and the <math alttext="t"><mi>t</mi></math>-coordinate of <math alttext="K"><mi>K</mi></math> is <math alttext="t subscript 2"> <msub> <mi>t</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> </math>.

(i) On the interval <math alttext="open parentheses t subscript 1 comma t subscript 2 close parentheses"><mfenced><mrow><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow></mfenced></math>, which of the following is true about <math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math> ?

a. <math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math> is positive and increasing.

b. <math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math> is positive and decreasing.

c. <math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math> is negative and increasing.

d. <math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math> is negative and decreasing.

(ii) On the interval <math alttext="open parentheses t subscript 1 comma t subscript 2 close parentheses"><mfenced><mrow><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow></mfenced></math>, describe the concavity of the graph of <math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math> and determine whether the rate of change of <math alttext="h"> <mi>h</mi> </math> is increasing or decreasing.
